results.title: Selection of dimensions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”

Introduces the principles which govern the choice of dimensions. These principles are shown to be based on two factors: (1) the functional characteristics of the object, which includes consideration of the accuracy demanded and the relation of the portion to other elements of the unit or machine; and (2) the manufacturing methods used in making the object.

results.title: Oblique cone and transitional developments
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
Animated drawings are used to show the development of the more complicated shapes. Shows an oblique cone, a transition connecting a circular and a square opening, and one connecting two curved openings. Demonstrates the use of true length diagrams and triangulation.

results.title: Simple developments
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
Animated drawings are used in explaining what simple developements are and how they are made. Shows step-by-step, the development of a hexangonal prism, truncated cylinder, right rectangular pyramid, oblique pyramid, right circular cone, and truncated right circular cone.

results.title: Sections and conventions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”

Explains why sectioning in engineering drawing is often necessary, and describes the various types of sectional views and the special language used.

results.title: Pictorial sketching
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
Animated drawings and live photography are used in explaining the basic principles of pictorial sketching. Describes the three methods of pictorial sketching, and explains where and how to use each method. Demonstrates a step-by-step procedure for sketching, from the initial visualisation to the checking of the completed sketch.

results.title: Drawings and the shop
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
Emphasises and describes the relationship between the making of the drawing and the various production operations in shop and factory. The flow of work, as called for in the various drawings of typical metal products, is traced through the pattern shop, the foundry, the forge shop, the machine shop, and the assembly shop. Representative operations in each of these departments is demonstrated.

results.title: Auxiliary views: single auxiliaries
results.creator_credit: McGraw-Hill Films and Pathescope Company of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
Begins with a brief review of the principles of orthographic projection and goes on to show that the three views obtained by projection on the three principal planes do not represent the true shape of some surfaces of an object that has one or more slanting faces. This condition is shown to require projection of the slanting surface on a plane which is parallel to it and not one of the principal planes. Thus auxiliary projection is explained and defined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: McGraw-Hill Films and Pathescope Company of America

results.title: Auxiliary views: double auxiliaries
results.creator_credit: McGraw-Hill Films and Pathescope Company of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
Begins with a quick view of orthographic projection on three principal planes and on auxiliary planes; then points out that a new condition is introduced if the object to be drawn has a slanting face that is not perpendicular to any of the principal planes. The film shows why a single auxiliary view does not give an accurate picture of an oblique face. The theory of double auxiliary or oblique view is then described in detail, using the visualization effects of combined animated drawings and animated models.

results.title: Training mannikin
results.creator_credit: Guy Fergusson and Stewart Hardy Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Emergency Resuscitation”
Intended mainly for first aid instructors but also of interest to first aid classes, the various ways in which a manikin may be used to train a class to perform both exhaled air resuscitation and closed chest cardiac massage are demonstrated by an instructor and his pupils. Care and maintenance of the manikin is illustrated as well as the hygienic precautions taken to safeguard users.
